block.p: Weeks
This
Last
On
Week
Week
List
Fiction
THE INDWELLING, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $22.99.) The seventh volume in a series about true believers who confront the Antichrist after the rapture of the saved. (+)
CRADLE AND ALL, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) A former nun turned private eye works on a case involving two virgins who become pregnant.
EASY PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $25.95.) The homicide detective Lucas Davenport investigates the strangulation of a famous model.
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a witchcraft school.
HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy's life at a school for witchcraft is threatened.

BEFORE I SAY GOOD-BYE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A woman with ESP searches for the truth behind the death of her husband, who was killed when his boat exploded in New York Harbor.
THE BLUEST EYE, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $15.) The story of an 11-year-old black girl -- pregnant by her father -- who prays for her eyes to turn blue.
THE BRETHREN, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) Three former judges, doing time at a federal prison in Florida, concoct a mail scam that goes awry.
STANDOFF, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $19.95.) A television reporter finds herself protecting the runaway teenage daughter of a multimillionaire from Texas.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $17.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
THE EMPTY CHAIR, by Jeffery Deaver. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Forensic specialists pursue a disturbed teenage boy who abducted two young women.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school for witchcraft.
STAR WARS: Rogue Planet, by Greg Bear. (Lucas/ Del Rey/Ballantine, $26.) Obi-Wan Kenobi and Anakin Skywalker are swept up in a world of deadly intrigue.
FIERCE INVALIDS HOME FROM HOT CLIMATES, by Tom Robbins. (Bantam, $27.50.) A C.I.A. operative named Switters goes on an erotic-spiritual quest.
ANIL'S GHOST, by Michael Ondaatje. (Knopf, $25.) A Sri Lankan woman who studied medicine abroad returns to examine the victims of her country's terror.
Weeks
This
Last
On
Week
Week
List
Nonfiction
FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS, by James Bradley with Ron Powers. (Bantam, $24.95.) The story of the men who raised the flag at Iwo Jima, by the son of one of them.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
FROM DAWN TO DECADENCE, by Jacques Barzun. (HarperCollins, $36.) A survey of 500 years of Western cultural life, from 1500 to the present.
NO SUCH THING AS A BAD DAY, by Hamilton Jordan. (Longstreet, $22.) A memoir by Jimmy Carter's chief of staff, who has survived three bouts with cancer.

IN THE HEART OF THE SEA, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $24.95.) The story of the whaleship Essex, whose disastrous fate in the early 19th century would later serve as inspiration for Herman Melville.
IT'S NOT ABOUT THE BIKE, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Putnam, $24.95.) A memoir by the Tour de France champion and cancer survivor.
KITCHEN CONFIDENTIAL, by Anthony Bourdain. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) A memoir-expose by the executive chef at Brasserie Les Halles in New York.
THE CAMINO, by Shirley MacLaine. (Pocket, $24.95.) A ''journey of the spirit'' takes the actress from present-day Spain through past lives to the origin of the universe.
*BOBOS IN PARADISE, by David Brooks. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A work of ''comic sociology'' that examines the rise of the bourgeois bohemians who constitute the new upper class.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War II.
THE MILLIONAIRE MIND, by Thomas J. Stanley. (Andrews McMeel, $26.95.) An analysis of the people who make up America's financial elite.
*ME TALK PRETTY ONE DAY, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) A collection of autobiographical comic essays by the author of ''Naked.''
*'TIS, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) An Irish immigrant gets used to life in America: the second volume of a memoir.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
PARENTHOOD BY PROXY, by Laura Schlessinger. (Cliff Street/HarperCollins, $24.) The radio talk show host offers a guide to getting families back on track.
Weeks
This
Last
On
Week
Week
List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous
WHO MOVED MY CHEESE? by Spencer Johnson. (Putnam, $19.95.) How to deal with changes at work and in life in general. (+)
TEN THINGS I WISH I'D KNOWN -- before i went out into the real world, by Maria Shriver. (Warner, $19.95.) Life lessons from the anchorwoman. (+)
SOUL STORIES, by Gary Zukav. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) Ways in which an understanding of the soul can transform one's life. (+)
*BODY FOR LIFE, by Bill Phillips with Michael D'Orso. (HarperCollins, $26.) Ways to improve one's body and one's life. (+)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending May 27, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.
And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

AMERICAN PHARAOH. Mayor Richard J. Daley: His Battle for Chicago and the Nation, by Adam Cohen and Elizabeth Taylor. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) A full-length biography of a politician many urban experts consider Chicago's personal savior, not just the Great Satan of the 1968 Democratic National Convention.

THE BINDING CHAIR: Or, A Visit From the Foot Emancipation Society, by Kathryn Harrison. (Random House, $24.95.) A resonant, elaborately constructed novel that renders the lives of two women, an aunt deformed physically and morally by tradition and her overtly rebellious niece.

ENGLISH PASSENGERS, by Matthew Kneale. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $25.) A grim but hilarious historical novel involving the extinction of the Tasmanians, a search for the Garden of Eden and a contrabandist from the Isle of Man.

EXPERIENCE, by Martin Amis. (Talk Miramax/ Hyperion, $23.95.) The novelist's nonfictional coming-of-age narrative, dense with personal history, firm opinions, literary gossip, name-dropping, wild regret, activist dentistry and Amis's father, Kingsley Amis.

NEW ADDRESSES: Poems, by Kenneth Koch. (Knopf, $23.) Fifty poems, each an ode to a different subject (''To Psychoanalysis,'' ''To My Father's Business,'' ''To 'Yes' ''), by a poet with plenty of affirmation and no fear of apostrophe.

O'NEILL: Life With Monte Cristo, by Arthur Gelb and Barbara Gelb. (Applause Books, $40.) The first volume of a reworking of the Gelbs' 1962 ''O'Neill,'' undertaken in the light of new information and recent cultural developments.

PASTORALIA: Stories, by George Saunders. (Riverhead, $22.95.) The author's second story collection focuses on the American urge for self-improvement, the fear of failure, the need to be accepted. Generally speaking, his characters don't stand the ghost of a chance.

THE SOCIAL LIVES OF DOGS: The Grace of Canine Company, by Elizabeth Marshall Thomas. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) A continuation of the author's 1993 best seller, ''The Hidden Life of Dogs,'' by an anthropologist who leaps over parochial limits to the proper study of mankind.

STERN MEN, by Elizabeth Gilbert. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) Gilbert's first novel concerns Maine fishermen on a pair of islands that are virtually at war; her protagonist, a smart, observant woman, teaches the uses of cooperation.

THE WATER IN BETWEEN: A Journey at Sea, by Kevin Patterson. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $23.95.) A bored Canadian doctor, 29, conceives the idea of sailing to Tahiti in a small boat. He does so, and lives. He writes this book. It is really quite charming and instructive. Lucky guy!
